text: I'm John Harwood with the New York Times
in CNBC in selecting Senator Joe Biden
of Delaware as his running mate Barack
Obama has added extensive political
experience knowledge of foreign policy
and a feisty middle-class sensibility to
the Democratic ticket he's calculating
that those assets far outweigh the
potential liabilities clouding his
message of change with a Washington
insider reviving the plagiarism
controversy that ended a Biden
presidential campaign 20 years ago and
risking mistakes by a senator who likes
to talk a lot Biden chairs the Senate
Foreign Relations Committee so he could
help Obama battle John McCain on
national security in 2002 he voted to
authorize the Iraq war which Obama
opposed meeting the desire Obama has
expressed now for an independent voice
within his administration he's a
Catholic a key constituency in Obama's
general election matchup with John
McCain he was born in coal country in
scranton pennsylvania a critical
electoral target and he's been on the
national stage for more than three
decades which might reassure voters
unsure about obama on the other hand
that long experience doesn't exactly fit
Obama's call for moving forward to a new
style of politics his first race for the
presidency in 1988 fell apart over
plagiarism charges that involved both
campaign rhetoric resembling that of a
British politician and a paper he wrote
during law school some Democrats also
worried Biden's loquacious style could
produce untimely gaffes during the
general election like the one he
apologized for last year when he
referred to Obama as the first
mainstream african-american candidate
whose articulate and bright and clean
but biden went on to perform well in
primary debates against Obama Hillary
Clinton and other rivals for this year's
nomination though that didn't win him
any primaries it persuaded Obama and his
team that Biden met one criteria that
most democratic strategists have called
critical in 2008 in his running mate
minimize risk
